input: Write a short biography of Bill Nye.
output: Bill Nye (born 1955) is an American science educator and television host. He began his career as an aerospace engineer and later became the CEO of The Planetary Society. He gained fame as the host of the science TV show "Bill Nye the Science Guy" from 1993-1998. Nye also wrote several books and hosted the Netflix show "Bill Nye Saves the World" in 2017. He is an advocate for science education and sustainability.

He studied mechanical engineering at Cornell University and worked in oil field service and consulting. In 1986, Nye joined Washington, D.C.'s Comedy Store and began performing stand-up comedy. He returned to TV with the 2017 Netflix series "Bill Nye Saves the World" and the 2018 Disney+ reboot "Bill Nye Saves the World." He has written several books on science and participated in the 2014 Ebola crisis.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC) was a Roman general and statesman who played a crucial role in the transformation of the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire. As a young man, he fought in the Gallic Wars under his uncle, Lucius Julius Caesar. After returning to Rome, Caesar became a popular senator and was elected consul in 59 BC. He then served as governor of Roman Gaul, where he subdued numerous tribes and made himself king of Rome's newest province. Returning to Rome, Caesar was appointed dictator for life in 48 BC, but his ambitious policies alienated many senators and led to his assassination in 44 BC.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman general and statesman, serving as Consul three times. He conquered Gaul and led the civil war that resulted in the end of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire. Caesar's military and political accomplishments made him the most powerful man in the empire. His assassination in 44 BCE is the subject of Shakespeare's play "Julius Caesar".

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Gaius Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC) was a Roman general and statesman, who rose to power during the Roman Republic. He was elected consul in 59 BC, a position that led to his military successes in the Gallic Wars and civil war with Pompey. Caesar gained further power through his alliances with Pompey and Crassus. After his conquest of Gaul, he attempted to cross the Rubicon River in 49 BC, precipitating a civil war. Caesar's forces ultimately won and he became dictator for life. He was assassinated in 44 BC by a group of senators.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman general and statesman who became dictator for life in 48 BCE. He is widely considered one of the most influential figures in world history and the Roman Republic's greatest orator and writer. Born into an old patrician family, Caesar was appointed military commander in Gaul (modern-day France) and defeated rival powers there. Returning to Rome, he was appointed Dictator for life by the Senate in 48 BCE. Caesar then turned to political reforms and ambitious military conquests in Europe, eventually winning civil war against the Senate. He was assassinated in 44 BCE by a group of senators.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman general, politician, and author who played a central role in the transition from the Roman Republic to the Roman Empire. Born into a prominent family, he became a military commander in Gaul and North Africa, winning many victories and gaining popular support. Caesar returned to Rome and entered politics, eventually rising to power. He was assassinated in 44 BCE by a group of senators, led by his former ally Marcus Brutus, who feared his growing power. The assassination prompted civil war, which ended with Caesar's heir Octavian, later known as Augustus, becoming sole ruler of the empire. Caesar's legacy as a military commander and political figure has had a profound influence on Western civilization.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Gaius Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman general, politician, and author. Caesar rose through the ranks to become one of the most powerful men in Rome, amassing immense wealth and influence. He fought in numerous wars and led successful campaigns in Gaul and Spain. Caesar's influence and popularity grew, earning him the epithet "dictator for life" in 44 BCE. Caesar's assassination in 44 BCE set off a period of civil war that ultimately led to the establishment of the Roman Empire. Caesar is remembered as one of the most influential figures in Roman history and is widely considered one of the greatest military commanders in history.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC) was a Roman statesman and general who became dictator of the Roman Republic. He fought numerous successful military campaigns, eventually expanding the Republic's territory into much of modern-day France and parts of Britain. Caesar was a talented orator and statesman, introducing many reforms and establishing the Julian Calendar. After his assassination, the Roman Republic fell into civil war, ending with the establishment of the Roman Empire under Augustus Caesar, Caesar's adopted son and successor.

His assassination in 44 BC led to a civil war and the rise of Octavian, who would become Emperor Augustus. input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) was a Roman politician and general who played a key role in the Roman Republic's transition to the Roman Empire. He rose to prominence as a military commander during the Gallic Wars and was appointed dictator. Caesar's political enemies assassinated him in 44 BC, leading to a civil war that ended with his nephew Octavian becoming Emperor Augustus. Caesar is best known for his conquests and military achievements, but his influence on Roman culture was also significant. He reformed the calendar and established a new coinage, and his influence on art, literature, and architecture was profound.

input: Write a short biography of Howard Zinn.
output: Howard Zinn (1922-2010) was an American historian, playwright, and activist known for his progressive views. He taught at Spelman College and Boston University and published the popular history "A People's History of the United States" in 1980. His writings focused on social justice and opposition to war. Zinn was a member of the Civil Rights Movement and participated in protests against the Vietnam War. He was a vocal critic of US foreign policy, opposing intervention in Central America, the invasion of Iraq, and the War on Terror. Zinn's works have been widely influential, inspiring generations of activists and scholars.

input: Write a short biography of Howard Zinn.
output: Howard Zinn (1922-2010) was an American historian, activist, and social critic. Born to a working-class Jewish family in Brooklyn, he served in World War II before pursuing a Ph.D. at Columbia University. Zinn became an influential voice of the American left, writing the bestselling A People's History of the United States (1980), which reframed the American Revolution as a struggle of oppressed people against the powerful. His other works include The Southern Civil Rights Movement (1984) and A Power Governments Cannot Suppress (1987). Zinn taught at Spelman College from 1964-1988, where he mentored civil rights activists like Julian Bond and Alice Walker.

output: Dian Fossey (1932-1985) was an American primatologist who studied mountain gorillas in Rwanda and Uganda. She studied at San Jose State University and the University of California, San Diego before spending over a decade conducting fieldwork in Africa. Fossey focused her research on the mountain gorilla subspecies, which at that time was considered to be endangered. Her research helped to establish a conservation approach known as the Fossey method, which involved habituating the gorillas to human presence. input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output: The Rolling Stones (formed 1962) are an English rock band widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential groups in music history. The band rose to prominence during the British Invasion with their 1964 song "I Wanna Be Your Man" and their 1965 hit "Satisfaction." Led by vocalist Mick Jagger and guitarist Keith Richards, they have a string of top-selling albums including "Beggars Banquet" (1968), "Exile on Main St." (1972), and "Tattoo You" (1981). The Stones have sold more than 200 million records worldwide, making them one of the best-selling music artists of all time. They have been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and the UK Music Hall of Fame, and are ranked as one of Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Artists of All Time.

input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output: The Rolling Stones (formed 1962) are an English rock band. They are considered one of the most influential bands in history, having helped create the "Rolling Stones Sound," a blend of blues and rock and roll. The band features Mick Jagger on vocals, Keith Richards on guitar, Charlie Watts on drums, and Ronnie Wood on guitar. In their early years, the band was led by Jagger and Keith, and its songwriting has been described as "mystical and cryptic." The Rolling Stones continue to tour and perform, with Jagger, Richards, Watts, and Wood as the core members. They have released more than 30 studio albums and have sold more than 200 million records worldwide.

input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output: The Rolling Stones are a British rock band founded in London in 1962. The band's lineup comprises vocalist and guitarist Mick Jagger, guitarist Keith Richards, bassist Charlie Watts, and drummer Ronnie Wood. Originally led by Jagger and Richards, the Rolling Stones were at the forefront of the British Invasion of bands that became popular in the US in 1964-65. Known for their wild stage antics, they became a symbol of the counterculture and released hits including "(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction" (1965) and "Honky Tonk Women" (1969). The Rolling Stones are widely regarded as one of the greatest bands of all time and remain active to this day.

Jordan is widely considered to be the greatest basketball player of all time.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist, conservationist, and ethologist best known for her study of chimpanzees. She began her career with a grant from the National Geographic Society, observing chimpanzees in the Gombe National Park in Tanzania. Goodall documented their tool use and communication, contributing to the understanding of great ape behavior and evolution. She co-founded the Jane Goodall Institute in 1977 to promote conservation, establishing community programs for healthcare and education. In 1979, Goodall was appointed UN Messenger of Peace.

input: Write a short biography of Melinda French Gates.
output: Melinda French Gates (born 1964) is an American businesswoman, philanthropist, and the former wife of Bill Gates. She worked at Microsoft from 1987-1999, leaving to focus on her family and charitable activities. In 2000, she and Bill Gates launched the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, focusing on global health and education. The Gates Foundation has committed over $50 billion in grants, with Melinda chairing its annual Goalkeepers event. She co-founded Pivotal Ventures, a social impact investment firm that invests in women-led organizations. Melinda has written two books and appears in the documentary "Inventing Tomorrow," about girls and women using technology to solve global problems.

input: Write a short biography of Melinda French Gates.
output: Melinda French Gates (born 1964) is an American businessperson, activist, and philanthropist. She co-founded Microsoft with Bill Gates, marrying him in 1994. French Gates launched Pivotal Ventures, a private, independent foundation, in 2015. It focuses on gender equality, reproductive rights, and empowering women. She has also advocated for global health, educational equity, and fighting climate change. French Gates stepped down from her role at Microsoft in 2020 to devote herself to philanthropy. She is a supporter of women's rights and public health causes, and a critic of the pornography industry.

input: Write a short biography of Melinda French Gates.
output: Melinda French Gates (born 1964) is an American businessperson and philanthropist. She is best known as the former wife of Bill Gates. Melinda was born in Dallas, Texas, and received an undergraduate degree in computer science from Duke University. She then worked for Microsoft for several years before leaving to focus on philanthropy with her husband. Melinda has been a longtime advocate for women's rights and has been an outspoken critic of global inequality. She founded the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which has donated billions of dollars to various charitable causes. The foundation also invests in technology and other industries. Melinda has authored several books, including "The Moment of Lift" and "Pivotal: How I Learned to Love the Work That Makes Me".

output: Oprah Winfrey (born 1954) is an American talk show host, actress, producer, and philanthropist. Born into poverty in rural Mississippi, Winfrey started working as a local TV reporter at age 19. She won a local Emmy for her coverage of the 1977 Mississippi-Alabama tornado outbreak, then began hosting "The Oprah Winfrey Show." input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69-30 BCE) was the last ruler of the Ptolemaic Dynasty in Egypt. She rose to power as co-regent for her brother Ptolemy XIII, and later became sole ruler. Cleopatra was involved in several wars between Rome and Egypt, eventually aligning herself with the Romans. She is famous for her affair with Julius Caesar, who was assassinated by conspirators in 44 BCE. After Caesar's death, Cleopatra's romance with Mark Antony led to a conflict with Octavian (the future emperor Augustus), who defeated her forces in 31 BCE. She committed suicide after the defeat. Cleopatra remains a figure of intrigue and mystery in the popular imagination, often portrayed as a sensual, seductive woman.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69-30 BC) was an Egyptian queen and last ruler of the Ptolemaic dynasty. She was a descendant of Greek conquerors and ruled jointly with her brothers for the first years of her reign. In 47 BC, she had herself declared queen, an act that alarmed Rome. She waged a civil war and seduced Julius Caesar, who supported her position. After Caesar's death, she consolidated her rule. She then allied with Rome's chief rival, the Parthian Empire, and ruled jointly with her brother-husband until his death. Following his death, she supported Mark Antony in the Roman civil war. In 30 BC, she and Antony committed suicide following their defeat in the Battle of Actium. Cleopatra was known for her beauty and charm, and she has been depicted in films, books, and art.

output: Cleopatra (69-30 BCE) was a queen of Egypt and one of the most powerful women in ancient history. She was the last Pharaoh of the Ptolemaic dynasty and became famous for her beauty and political skills. Cleopatra was a polyglot who learned to speak numerous languages, including Greek and Egyptian. She was a patron of the arts and sciences and a strong advocate for cultural unity. Through her alliance with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony, she sought to strengthen Egypt's political and economic ties with Rome. Cleopatra was ultimately betrayed by Antony and died in 30 BCE.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra VII (69 BC-30 BC) was a Queen of Egypt and member of the Ptolemaic Dynasty. She ruled Egypt as co-ruler with her father Ptolemy XII and eventually took full control. Cleopatra became a political ally of Julius Caesar and then Mark Antony after the Romans ousted the Ptolemys. Cleopatra's story has become part of popular culture and she is often depicted as a seductive and powerful ruler.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69-30 BC) was the last ruler of the Ptolemaic dynasty in Egypt. She came to power at 18 after her father died, forming a triumvirate with her two brothers. Cleopatra eventually overthrew them and ruled as pharaoh. She cultivated relationships with Roman politicians Julius Caesar and Mark Antony, whom she married. After Caesar's assassination, Antony fought with the Roman Senate, ultimately committing suicide with Cleopatra in Egypt. Cleopatra's legacy includes the formation of the Library of Alexandria. She remains a popular cultural icon, depicted in books, plays, and movies.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69-30 BC) was the last ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt. Born into a Macedonian Greek family that had ruled Egypt for three centuries, Cleopatra became Queen at age 18 after her father's death. She used her seductive powers to further her political aims, including alliances with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony. Cleopatra's downfall began when her lover Mark Antony was defeated by Octavian (later Augustus Caesar). Octavian had Cleopatra and her children executed, ending the Ptolemaic Dynasty. Cleopatra remains an iconic figure in Western culture, known for her beauty, intelligence, and ambition.

input: Write a short biography of Aretha Franklin.
output: Aretha Franklin (1942-2018) was an American singer, songwriter, pianist, and activist. She began her career singing gospel music in her father's church and signed to Columbia Records at 18. In 1960, she released "Aretha Franklin Sings the Great Diva Classics" on RCA Records. In 1967, Franklin recorded the landmark gospel-inflected song "Respect," a global hit that established her as a figurehead of soul. The 1968 live album "Aretha: A Grammy Celebration for Aretha Franklin" won her six Grammy Awards, including "Album of the Year" and "Record of the Year." Franklin's influence stretched across music genres, inspiring artists like Otis Redding and Beyonce. She is often cited as the Queen of Soul, and Rolling Stone magazine placed her among the 100 Greatest Singers of All Time.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.
output: Wangari Maathai (1940-2011) was a Kenyan environmental activist, politician, and the first African woman to receive the Nobel Peace Prize. Born in a small village, she studied at Kenya University, then worked as an assistant lecturer before earning her PhD in 1971 at the University of Pittsburgh. After returning to Kenya, she founded the Green Belt Movement, organizing communities to plant trees to prevent soil erosion and deforestation. In 1982, she ran for parliament, losing narrowly. She won in 1992 and was reelected in 1997, leading the Green Party to join with other parties to form the National Rainbow Coalition. She was appointed Assistant Minister of Environment and Natural Resources, then Minister in 2003. After losing her bid for reelection, she continued her work with the Green Belt Movement, speaking out on issues of climate change.

output: Rosa Louise McCauley Parks (1913-2005) was a civil rights activist who played a key role in the Montgomery bus boycott. Parks, an Alabama native, was arrested after refusing to give up her seat on a bus to a white man. Her refusal led to the Montgomery bus boycott and helped spark the civil rights movement. input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Parks (1913-2005) was an African-American civil rights activist who is considered one of the most important figures in the civil rights movement. She worked for years to end segregation in buses, lunch counters, theaters, schools, and public places. input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian writer and novelist. She is best known for her 2006 novel "Half of a Yellow Sun" and her 2013 TED Talk "The Danger of a Single Story." Adichie attended both American and Nigerian universities before earning a master's degree at Johns Hopkins University. Her novels "Americanah" and "Purple Hibiscus" were well received, and she has also written non-fiction, short stories, and children's books. Adichie's work explores themes of identity, belonging, and the impact of colonialism.

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian author and feminist. She was raised in the Igbo tradition, studied medicine in the United States, and became interested in literature while working as a doctor in Nigeria. Her novels and short stories explore feminism, race, immigration, and the African diaspora. Adichie's works include “Half of a Yellow Sun,” “Americanah,” and “Dear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions.” She has won multiple awards, including the Commonwealth Prize, Orange Prize, and Dayton Literary Peace Prize. Adichie is a public intellectual and has written for publications such as the New York Times, the Washington Post, and The Guardian.

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian novelist and essayist. Her novels, short stories, and essays focus on the lives of women in Africa. Adichie grew up in Nigeria and studied at Drexel University and Cornell University. Her debut novel Purple Hibiscus (2003) received several awards, and she later released Half of a Yellow Sun (2006), Americanah (2013), and Dear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions (2017). Adichie's books have been translated into 30 languages. Her TED talk, "The Danger of a Single Story," has been viewed over 4 million times.

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian novelist and non-fiction writer. She received her master's degree from Johns Hopkins University and studied at the Iowa Writers' Workshop. Her novels include Purple Hibiscus (2003), Americanah (2013), and Half of a Yellow Sun (2006), which was adapted into a film. Her essays and speeches address themes of feminism, race, and immigration. Adichie also writes for children, including her popular children's book, "The Worst Thing About My Sister." She has won a number of awards, including the MacArthur "Genius" Grant and the National Book Critics Circle Award.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a Serbian professional tennis player and one of the greatest athletes in the sport's history. After training with his father, Srdjan, Djokovic turned pro in 2003. With 22 Grand Slam titles, he is tied for third in men's history. In the Open Era (since 1968), only Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer have won more. Djokovic has won Wimbledon six times and the French Open three times, among other titles. With 375 career weeks as world #1, he is the fourth-ranked player in that category. He is known for his mental toughness and powerful strokes.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) was an Indian politician and the Prime Minister of India from 1966-1977 and 1980-1984. Gandhi was the eldest daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru, who served as the first Prime Minister of India. Gandhi studied at the University of Oxford and joined the Indian National Congress Party. She served as a member of parliament from 1964-1984. In 1966, Gandhi assumed power as the Prime Minister of India, becoming the first woman to hold the office. Her tenure was marked by military conflicts with Pakistan and internal political divisions. Gandhi faced criticism for using emergency powers to crack down on dissent, and she was assassinated by her Sikh bodyguards in 1984.

input: Write a short biography of Spencer Tracy.
output: Spencer Tracy (1900-1967) was a versatile American actor who rose to fame in the 1930s. He had an extensive career in film and theater, winning an Academy Award for Best Actor for the film "Inherit the Wind" (1960). Known for his naturalistic acting style, Tracy worked with some of the most notable directors of his era, including Alfred Hitchcock, William Wyler, and Stanley Kramer. input: Write a short biography of Tina Turner.
output: Tina Turner (born Anna Mae Bullock, 1939) is an American singer, songwriter, and actress. She began her career as a teenager singing and playing piano with Ike Turner's Kings of Rhythm. Turner's solo career began in 1966 with the album "United States of America." She is best known for her hits "Proud Mary," "Nutbush City Limits," and "River Deep - Mountain High." She won eight Grammys and a Golden Globe during her career and was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 1991. Turner is the first artist to receive the Billboard Icon Award, honoring her career longevity and influence.

input: Write a short biography of Tina Turner.
output: Tina Turner (born 1939) is an American-Swiss singer and songwriter. She rose to fame as a member of the Ikettes, performing alongside Ike Turner, with whom she married in 1962. After divorcing Ike in 1978, she released the solo album "Private Dancer," which was a commercial and critical success. input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919) was a Polish-German revolutionary and socialist theorist. She was one of the leaders of the German Social Democratic Party (SPD) during the early 20th century. Luxemburg opposed both the World War I and the Treaty of Versailles. She was critical of the Bolsheviks, arguing that a democratic socialist society should be based on federalism rather than centralized power. She was murdered by the Freikorps during a Nazi-led insurrection. Luxemburg's writings influenced many left-wing political movements throughout Europe.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1871-1919) was a German Marxist political theorist and revolutionary socialist. Born in Poland, Luxemburg joined the Social Democrat Party in her teens and studied at the University of Zurich. After serving as secretary for the Social Democrat Party in Berlin, Luxemburg founded the Spartacus League and the newspaper Die Rote Fahne. She was a prominent member of the German Socialist Workers' Party and a leader in the November Revolution. After the fall of the monarchy, Luxemburg opposed the signing of the Treaty of Versailles, which she believed undermined the German Revolution. Arrested and tortured during the Spartacist Revolt, she was shot by a soldier on the night of 15 January 1919. Luxemburg's legacy includes her writings on Marxism, anarchism, imperialism, and feminism.

output: Bob Marley (1945-1981) was a Jamaican reggae singer and songwriter. Marley rose to prominence in the 1970s, and his music was a significant influence on reggae, Rastafarian culture, and global popular music. His lyrics explored themes of love, spirituality, and social justice, and he became an iconic figure of the anti-apartheid movement. After a brief career as a soccer player, Marley joined the vocal group the Wailers and released several albums, including "Catch a Fire" (1973), which brought him international attention. He later founded his own record label and continued to release albums, including "Uprising" (1980) and "Survival" (1979). Marley died of cancer in 1981 at the age of 36, but his legacy lives on in his music and the Marley family's efforts to promote Rastafarian culture and social justice causes.

Mendes is one of the world's most successful artists, with over 35 million albums sold worldwide.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1871-1919) was a Polish-born Marxist philosopher, revolutionary, and anti-war activist. She was one of the most influential theorists of European socialism and international socialist theory. Born to an upper-middle-class Jewish family in what is now Poland, Luxemburg became active in the Polish Social Democratic Party in the late 1890s. After emigrating to Germany in 1904, she became a leading figure in the German Social Democratic Party and one of its founders. After World War I broke out in 1914, she became one of the leading voices of the anti-war movement in Germany and Europe. She was assassinated by far-right Freikorps soldiers at the age of 47 during the Berlin uprising. Luxemburg is considered one of the most important philosophers of socialism and anti-war movements, as well as a leading figure in the development of the ideology of the communist movement.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1871-1919) was a Polish-German Marxist revolutionary and socialist theorist. Born in Russia, Luxemburg moved to Germany as a teenager. In 1904, she co-founded the Social Democratic Party's revolutionary wing, the Spartacist League. She was one of the leaders of the German Revolution in 1918-19, but was imprisoned in 1919 and murdered by the Freikorps. A prolific writer, Luxemburg is best known for her Marxist critique of revisionist ideas, her defense of Marxism, and her belief in class struggle.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1871-1919) was a German socialist revolutionary and theorist. She joined the Social Democratic Party (SPD) as a young woman, working as a journalist and publishing many essays and books. Luxemburg left the SPD in 1914 in opposition to its support for World War I. She became a leading figure of the anti-war movement and Marxist opposition to war. After the November Revolution, Luxemburg became active in the new Communist Party of Germany, forming the Red Flag group. She was murdered by right-wing militants while in police custody during the Spartacist uprising. Luxemburg's ideas influenced Marxist thought and remain influential in socialist and feminist movements.
